questions.question_text:
Company iPads are enrolled in Systems Manager without supervision, and profiles are pushed through Systems Manager.
Which outcome occurs when a user attempts to remove the “Meraki Management” profile on an iPad?

comments.content: You have this situation if you remove the device from the system manager. The question is whether the user manually removes it from the device.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Solely removing a device from the Systems Manager Dashboard network will not have any immediate impact on the device, except prevent further MDM management until the device is re-enrolled. Any apps or profiles that are already pushed to a device will remain active will remain on the device.

Selected Answer: C
I´m doubt yet, but I´ll go with C !
The documentation says:
iOS/iPadOS
Non ADE enrolled devices
For devices that were enrolled via manual profile installation, the profile can be removed via the UI on the device, or via SM if the device is actively checking in.

UI removal of enrollment profile:

1- On the device, navigate to Settings > General > Device Management.

2- Select Meraki Management, and select Remove to delete the management profile and any managed configuration profiles installed via SM. 

Ref.: https://documentation.meraki.com/SM/Device_Enrollment/Uninstalling_Systems_Manager_and_Removing_Managed_Devices

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer.

Also going with C.
On the device, navigate to Settings > General > Device Management
Select Meraki Management, and select Remove to delete the management profile and any managed configuration profiles installed via SM

C is the correct answer.
Assuming the profile removal policy is set to 'Allow user to remove this profile'.

choices.B: The “Meraki Management” profile is removed and then pushed automatically by Systems Manager.
choices.A: The “Meraki Management” profile cannot be removed.
choices.D: The “Meraki Management” profile is removed. All the profiles Systems Manager pushed remain.
choices.C: The “Meraki Management” profile is removed. All the profiles that Systems Manager pushed are also removed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
https://documentation.meraki.com/SM/Monitoring_and_Reporting/MDM_Commands_in_Systems_Manager
 - Under Live Tools
Selective Wiping is only for MacOS. Here we have Windows Laptop as well

Selected Answer: DE
Send notification also available on Windows OS. Poor question.

Selected Answer: CE
selective wipe and remote desktop are two Systems Manager Live tools that are only available for Apple Macs and Windows PCs.

comments.content:
Nope, not correct. The oldest comment in this thread as a link that proves that wrong. Selective wipe can be used on mobile devices. Screenshots can only be done on Windows and macOS machines.

DE is correct.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Answer: D and E

D and E
Troubleshooting and Live Tools:
Remote device lock, unlock, and wipe (Android, iOS, Mac, and Windows)
Remote reboot and shutdown (Mac and Windows)
Remote desktop and screenshot (Mac and Windows)
Access device process list (Mac and Windows)
Send instant notification to device (Android, iOS, Mac, and Windows)
Monitor active TCP connections, TCP stats, and routing table (Mac and Windows)
Selective Wipe (Android, iOS, and Mac)
Toggle voice, data roaming, and hotspot (iOS)
Command Kiosk-mode or Single App mode on demand (Android and iOS)
Initiate Airplay remotely (iOS)

questions.question_text: Which two Systems Manager Live tools are available only for Apple Macs and Windows PCs and cannot be used on iOS or Android mobile devices? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer: D for sure
You´ll find the explanation in the official Meraki´s documentation:

Appliance Network with Two MXs in an HA Configuration
When MX appliances configured to operate in High Availability (HA)

The Primary MX downloads firmware
The Primary MX stops advertising VRRP
The Secondary MX becomes active
The Primary MX reboots
The Primary MX comes online again
The Primary MX starts advertising VRRP again
The Primary MX becomes active again
The Secondary MX downloads firmware (approximately 15 minutes after the original upgrade is scheduled)
The Secondary MX stops advertising VRRP
The Secondary MX reboots and comes back online

https://documentation.meraki.com/Architectures_and_Best_Practices/Cisco_Meraki_Best_Practice_Design/Best_Practices_for_Meraki_Firmware#Appliance_Network_with_Two_MXs_in_an_HA_Configuration

Selected Answer: D
According to azjlmpang's explanation it must be D!

Selected Answer: D
Correct is D
Correct Answer: D
Should be D. NOT A, sorry.

Selected Answer: A
1. The Primary MX downloads firmware
2. The Primary MX stops advertising VRRP
3. The Secondary MX becomes active
4. The Primary MX reboots
5. The Primary MX comes online again
6. The Primary MX starts advertising VRRP again
7. The Primary MX becomes active again
8. The Secondary MX downloads firmware (approximately 15 minutes after the original upgrade is scheduled)
9. The Secondary MX stops advertising VRRP
10. The Secondary MX reboots and comes back online

https://documentation.meraki.com/Architectures_and_Best_Practices/Cisco_Meraki_Best_Practice_Design/Best_Practices_for_Meraki_Firmware

comments.content: ops... now I did the same mistake, the answer is D... sorry... LoL

your reference is correct, but your interpretation is wrong (or, you missclicked in the wrong answer) the Answer is A, for sure!
I´ll answer with the same link you did

questions.question_text: Which order is accurate for a firmware upgrade on MX appliances in a high-availability configuration?

choices.D: starts on the primary MX appliance and then occurs on the secondary MX appliance
choices.A: starts on the secondary MX appliance and then occurs on the primary MX appliance
choices.B: starts on both MX appliances at the same time and then reboots both appliances after traffic on the primary MX appliance ceases
choices.C: starts on both MX appliances at the same time and then immediately reboots both appliances

questions.question_text: Which three verbs of request are available in the Cisco Meraki API? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BEF
The Cisco Meraki API supports several HTTP verbs (methods) for making requests. The three primary verbs of request available in the Cisco Meraki API are:

 GET: This verb is used to retrieve information from the server. It is commonly used to get details about networks, devices, and configurations.

 POST: This verb is used to create new resources or submit data to the server. For example, it can be used to create new networks, add devices, or configure settings.

 PUT: This verb is used to update existing resources. It is typically used to modify configurations or update details of existing resources like devices and networks.

Other verbs like DELETE are also supported, which are used to delete resources, but the three primary ones are GET, POST, and PUT.

Selected Answer: BEF
Correct: B, E and F

Selected Answer: BEF
Verbs in the API follow the usual REST conventions:
GET returns the value of a resource or a list of resources, depending on whether an identifier is specified.
POST adds a new resource
PUT updates a resource
DELETE removes a resource

https://documentation.meraki.com/General_Administration/Other_Topics/Cisco_Meraki_Dashboard_API

questions.question_text: Which Meraki Dashboard menu section is accessed to enable Sentry enrollment on an SSID?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
SM Sentry enrollment can be enabled on any MR network via the Splash page section of the Wireless > Configure > Access control page.

https://documentation.meraki.com/MR/MR_Splash_Page/Systems_Manager_Sentry_Enrollment

Selected Answer: A
To configure Sentry Enrollment on an SSID, one can Set the splash page on an SSID to Endpoint management enrollment by going to the wireless access control page of the Meraki dashboard then Select the radio button that enables Systems Manager Sentry enrollment

Selected Answer: A
Correct: A

https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwiqw4OCg9aAAxUwhv0HHfvjANsQFnoECA0QAw&url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocumentation.meraki.com%2FMR%2FMR_Splash_Page%2FSystems_Manager_Sentry_Enrollment%23%3A~%3Atext%3DSM%2520Sentry%2520enrollment%2520can%2520be%2C%253E%2520Configure%2520%253E%2520Access%2520control%2520page.&usg=AOvVaw0cZ5QceGFK9I7LIRsGuD0R&opi=89978449
